rows.block1_text::eng:
**Routines – Fraction Areas – Rectangle Fractions**

The challenge is to identify the fraction of the whole design that each color has (considering all pieces of one color together).

You have several choices for how to present these to your students using dividing lines. You can present them with minimal lines, no lines, or with extra lines. Using extra lines provides practice with identifying equivalent fractions. For example, in the first diagram (using all modes), the blue section can be seen as 3/8, 6/16, or 12/32.
rows.block2_text::eng: These diagrams are presented in pairs, but the two diagrams are not related.
rows.block4_text::eng: When there are two pieces of identical size, that can be used to find alternative ways to do things. The puzzle below and to the left is broken into halves. In it, the blue region is 2/3 of its half, so it is 1/3 of the whole diagram. You can also see this by noticing that the yellow and red pieces have the same total size as the blue or the purple piece. In the puzzle below and to the right, the yellow piece is made up of two of the red or purple pieces, so the pieces have sizes 1/4, 1/4, and 1/2.

These diagrams are presented in unrelated pairs.

**Routines – Fraction Areas – Unusual Baker**

The story for these diagrams is that there is an unusual baker that likes to cut his cakes into odd shaped pieces. He likes to charge $10 for the whole cake, and he wants to know how much he should charge for each piece. The two cutting patterns in each pair are unrelated puzzles.
rows.block7_text::eng: These last two diagrams are harder than the rest. For the diagram on the left, note that the inner square has area 1/4 of the lerger square – as one way to see this, break the whole diagram into little triangles the same size as the ones in the middle. The tricky part of the diagram on the right is that the two triangles have the same area. See this by adding some additional lines to the right half of that diagram – a vertical line down its middle, a horizontal line across its middle, and finish the diagonal that starts in the upper right and ends in the lower left – this produces eight idential right triangles.
